messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> It's silly, but do you /have/ to use floating-point numbers? I have to
> admit, I haven't used one in years, because floating-point arithmetic
> irks me.

I'm not the OP ( Anna Skawinska )
and I generally don't do "me too" posts, but
JB is on to a critical question. In general, Djkstra was wrong,
it should have been "float considered harmful" for 99% of
programmers and programs. Use of floating point
arithmetic is to be avoided because it is a bug farm.

It is criminal to use floating point when you want to represent
money, and in many other cases, fixed point is vastly
superior. Clearly some subfields need it, engineering calculations,
FFT, DSP, etc. But I've been a professional developer
for over 30 years, and I've only had two cases (each for only
a few months each) where using floating point was
the correct answer.

Proper numerical analysis and algorithms for floating point
numbers is an art, and there are many non-obvious problems.
Rapid/Extreme programming is not well suited to
floating point work (and double and even quad precision don't
address the fundamental problems.)

If you have a choice, don't use float.
